page.title: 02The Canal
page.content: The correct name for the Canal which runs through Heybridge is the Chelmer and Blackwater Navigation. It was built between 1793 to 1797 and cost Â£50,000. The principal engineer was John Rennie who employed Irish navigators or navvies to cut the canal using picks and shovels. The canal then had to be made waterproof by puddling a mixture of loam and clay. It is the only canal in Essex and the shallowest in England, being only a metre in depth in places. It runs between Heybridge Basin and Chelmsford and is 20 kilometres long and has 11 locks and one sea lock at the Basin. For most of its length it is not a true canal but a canalised river, the only real cut being between the Basin and Heybridge itself.
